sentences: On 2 March 2016, Ms Sharapova was charged with an   Rule Violation under Article 2.
The tribunal found that Sharapova’s violation ”was not intentional” because she ”did not appreciate that Mildronate contained a substance prohibited from 1 January 2016”.

A   report of the tribunal’s findings said: ”The ITF accepts that the player did not engage in conduct that she knew constituted an antidoping rule violation,” but it rejected her assertion that there was no ”significant” fault on her part.
In a statement, Sharapova once again claimed that she did not intentionally violate tennis’s   rules and said she would appeal her ban to the Court of Arbitration for Sport in Switzerland.

“The player’s case is that she did not know that the active ingredient of Mildronate [a marketed form of meldonium] a medication which she had regularly been using for over 10 years, had been added to the Prohibited List from 1 January 2016 and she did not intentionally contravene the   rules in using Mildronate at the Australian Open,” the decision reads.

The World   Agency (WADA) later issued a short statement saying it would review the decision before deciding whether to use its independent right of appeal to CAS Sharapova has regularly battled back from serious injuries during her glittering career but the   ban means she will not be eligible to play until after the 2018 Australian Open when she will be 30, and raises the question of whether she will ever play again.

”If it stands, then I think it will be difficult for her to come back at the same level,” the president of the Russian Tennis Federation, Shamil Tarpishchev, told TASS news agency, calling for the penalty to be reduced.

It’s unclear how long it takes for meldonium to exit an athlete’s system, and WADA told the world’s sporting federations in April that athletes who have tested positive for meldonium may be able to avoid sanctions if they can prove they took it before it was banned on Jan. 1.
The ITF    which sought a   punishment    told CNN it wouldn’t be appealing to CAS, while the World   Agency will review the decision before deciding whether or not to take the matter to   court.
Meldonium became a banned substance this year under the WADA code, and Sharapova claims she didn’t notice its addition to the banned list.

The tribunal found that while she had not intentionally contravened   rules, she bore sole responsibility for the substance being in her system during the Australian Open and for her failure to notice that the drug had been added to the banned list.
Sharapova, who has continued to promote her candy company Sugarpova since being suspended, said she simply failed to read an email that stated meldonium would be added to the banned list on Jan. 1.

Taken together with the evidence that over a period of 3 years she did not disclose her use of Mildronate to her coach, trainer, physio, nutritionist or any medical adviser she consulted through the WTA, the facts are only consistent with a deliberate decision to keep secret from the   authorities the fact that she was using Mildronate in competition.
She says the ITF wanted to ban her for four years, but it was reduced to two years by a   Tennis   Program tribunal because the ITF had not found evidence that Sharapova’s doping was intentional.
She also said that the ITF wanted to suspend her for four years, but the independent tribunal tasked with investigating her violation settled for two after she promptly admitted to taking the drug.
”The ITF tribunal unanimously concluded that what I did was not intentional,” the    Sharapova said.
“While the tribunal concluded correctly that I did not intentionally violate the   rules, I cannot accept an unfairly harsh   suspension,” Sharapova said.

“The ITF accepts that she did not know that Mildronate contained a Prohibited Substance but argues that in taking the medication she knowingly and manifestly disregarded the risk of contravening the   rules, and thus committed an intentional violation.

That means she will forfeit ”the ranking points and prize money that she won at the event,” according to the tribunal statement.
